By the way, you can find some papers by the
NaturalMotion people before they started the
company(search for Torsten Reil, Colm Massey, and Phil
Husbands).  

One thing that helps limit the search space in this
domain is using PD/PID (proportional derivative or
proportional integral derivative) controllers on some
of the joints.  This is something NaturalMotion uses. 
They are basically models of damped torsional springs.
 They simply continuously add torques to a joint to
maintain a desired angle and can be used effectively
on controlled and uncontrolled joints.  

I'm using something like this in my project.  Open
Dynamics Engine has joints with "motor" parameters;
each joint can have a desired velocity and max torque.
 I use the current joint angle and desired joint angle
(output from neural net) to compute the desired
velocity at the controlled joints.  The uncontrolled
joints simply try maintain their initial angle.

Tyler

--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> In a similar vein, I noticed that the physical model
> is not accurate, because the final "good" walker has
> it's feet well to the right & left of the center of
> gravity, and yet there is no side-to-side wobble. 
> Furthermore the motion of each leg appears to be
> planar.  Two legs each doing planar motion in
> different planes will not be stable in the real
> world;
> it will wobble from side to side with increasing
> amplitude.  I think the demo is "rigged".
